title: Duchess of Sussex undertakes "personal" engagement on South Africa royal tour
text:
From Harper's BAZAAR

The royal tour of South Africa is well underway with a large number of engagements still left to tick from the couple's itinerary.

But the Duchess of Sussex made sure to take time out to "show solidarity against gender based violence and femicide" in a personal pitstop.

The royal stopped by the post office where 19-year-old University of Cape Town student, Uyinene Mrwetyana, was raped and murdered last month.

Moved by the scene, the Duchess of Sussex tied a yellow ribbon at the site emblazoned with words in the local language of Xhosa which translate to: "We stand together in this moment."

According to Kensington Palace, Harry and Meghan had been following the story from the UK and the Duchess of Sussex met with Mrwetyana's mother to relay their condolences.









A Buckingham Palace spokeswoman said: "We can confirm that earlier this week The Duchess made a private visit to the memorial of Uyinene Mrwetyana.

Exclusive: #Meghan made a secret trip to pay tribute to #Uyinene Mrwetyana whose brutal murder has outraged South Africa. The Duchess was so shocked by the torture, rape and murder of the beautiful student she made a top-secret pilgrimage to the post office where she was killed. pic.twitter.com/vCy4uPW7cR — Emily Andrews (@byEmilyAndrews) September 27, 2019

"Having closely followed the tragic story, it was a personal gesture she wanted to make."

The crime sparked global outrage and the Duchess of Sussex has spent the last two days trying to deepen her understanding of the situation with the aim to advocate for women and girls' rights across the globe.

Photo credit: Pool/Samir Hussein - Getty Images More

The Duchess of Sussex was last seen in public on Wednesday (September 25) when she visited not-for-profit organisation, Mothers2Mothers, which trains and employs women living with HIV as frontline health workers.

In a sweet gesture, the royal donated some of her son Archie's outgrown clothing to other babies in need.

Earlier that day, the four-month-old tot made his debut royal engagement to meet Archbishop Desmond Tutu.
